blog.description: I still believe in summer days, the seasons always change and life will find a way. Masterlist Ships (closed) Wattpad

title: Northern Lights
body:
Summary: Rosalie Tyrell finds herself in a dangerous game of hearts when she catches the eye of more than one man: Robb Stark, the honourable heir of Winterfell, Jon Snow, dashing bastard of the North and Jamie Lannister, the proud knight of the King’s guard. Winter is coming and the war is quickly upon them, and as fate would have it they will find themselves each on a different path, but only one leads to her.

Pairing: Robb Stark x OC, Jon Snow x OC, Jaime Lannister x OC

“A rose thrusted in a world of wolves and lions is quick to grow sharp thorns.”

Northern Lights Series

summary: Jon Snow and daenerys Targaryen parallel scenes
title: Jon Snow and daenerys Targaryen parallel scenes
body:
And this idiot Jonsas are talking about ‘’parallels’’? their whole storyline is practicaly  parallel of each other 

Two side of same coin 

Jonerys is Destiny

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: A strange thought has just appeared in my mind!  When I was watching this scene before I only interpreted Littlefinger's words...
caption:
A strange thought has just appeared in my mind! 

When I was watching this scene before I only interpreted Littlefinger’s words being about  that prostitute whose name I don’t remember (“Many who try to climb it fail and never get to try again. The fall breaks them. ”), Sansa (“And some are given a chance to climb, but they refuse. They cling to the realm or the gods or love. Illusions. ”) and Jon (“Only the ladder is real. The climb is all there is.”). Which is kind of obvious. 

BUT!  This could actually be a foreshadowing of Joffrey’s death (he tried to be a King and was poisoned, so the fall broke him), Shae’s death (she was given a chance to leave King’s Landing by ship too! And she was cling to love, not Sansa!)  and Jon’s path of becoming a King (he climbed the Wall following Ygritte, his first love, the one he lost later; but this part of the quote is not about love, it says “the climb is all there is”, so I guess he will lose Daenerys too).﻿Свернуть

tags: i saw a hilarious stannis one and i had to

summary: GAME OF THRONES SEASON 8 EPISODE LENGTHS HAVE REPORTEDLY BEEN LEAKED
title: GAME OF THRONES SEASON 8 EPISODE LENGTHS HAVE REPORTEDLY BEEN LEAKED
body:
The episodes lengths for the six final episodes of Game Of Thrones have reportedly been leaked. Whilst we have heard previously that each episode will be feature length, this supposed leak (which should be taken with a grain of salt) suggests that this may not entirely be the case. 

The report comes from French magazine, Premiere, and seems to suggest that the first two episodes will be 60 minutes in length, which was about the average for a Game Of Thrones episode during Season 7, whilst the final 4 episodes will clock in at 80 minutes each.

There’s no official word from HBO about any of this so we’ll just have to wait and see.

summary:
From Jon Snow's logbook: DAY 7
Davos, you mistake titles, I am a King, not a captain!
BUT when she discovered I had a logbook...
body:
From Jon Snow’s logbook: DAY 7

Davos, you mistake titles, I am a King, not a captain!

BUT when she discovered I had a logbook too she started to call me that.

I might change my title just to hear her say that word near my name with that wicked look of her while I…err…workship the…expanse of her womanly parts…fuck Davos stop reading

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: Will Arya kill Da€nerys? - More tidbits from Fire and Blood
title: Will Arya kill Da€nerys? - More tidbits from Fire and Blood
body:
We are currently discussing this possible scenario over at @delulumeta and while looking at Fire and Blood I came across this story, which is a clear hint at Arya killing D and I just couldn’t resist the temptation to share this.

Moon’s murder removed the last major obstacle to the acession of Jaehaerys Targaryen to the Iron Throne, but from that day to this, debate has raged as to who was responsible for his death. No one truly believed that the woman who attempted to poison the “sinful septon” and ended by cutting his throat was acting on her won. Plainly she was but a catspaw … but whose? Did the boy king himself send her forth, or was she mayhaps an agent of his Hand, Rogar Baratheon, or his mother, the Queen Regent? Some came to believe that the woman was one of the Faceless Men, the infamous guild of sorcerer-assassins from Braavos. In support of this claim, they cited her sudden disappearance, the way she seemed to “melt into the night” after the murder, and the fact that Septon Moon’s guards could not agree on what she looked like.

Wiser man and those familiar with the ways of the Faceless Men give this theory little credence. The very clumsiness of Moon’s murder speaks against it being their work, for the Faceless Men take great care to make their killings appear as natural deaths. It is a point of pride with them, the very cornerstone of their art. Slitting a man’s throat and leaving him to stagger forth into the night screaming of murder is beneath them. Most scholars today believe that the killer was no more than a camp follower, acting at the behest of either Lord Rowan or Lord Oakheart, or mayhaps the both of them. Though neither dared desert Moon whilst he live, the alacrity with which the two lords abandoned his cause after his death suggests that their grievance had been with Maegor, not with House Targaryen…. and indeed, both men would soon return to Oldtown, penitent and obedient, to bend the knee before Prince Jaehaerys at his coronation. (Fire and Blood, The Ascencion of Jaehaerys I).

So, we have a female assassin who is a faceless man or maybe not - just like Arya is a female assassin who is not a real faceless man. She left the House of Black and White before her education was formerly over. Like Arya in the mercy chapter this female assassin kills her target by seducing him and then slitting his throat. In the show the ‘slitting a man’s throat’ has become something like a trademark for Arya. Also the woman meling into the night may evoke the “quiet as a shadow”-stealthiness that Arya already learned with Syrio Forel. It is also interesting that the word catspaw is used. It could be an allusion to Cat = Catelyn as Arya’s mother or to the dagger Arya wears in the show. We don’t know the dagger’s name in the books yet, but the show gives it as catspaw.

But why Da€nerys as the victim? Septon Moon is the last obstacle against the acession of Jaehaerys I, a king who clearly has parallels to Jon, Da€nerys is the last obstacle to Jon’s acession. It is also interesting that a Baratheon is involved, which might point towards the fact that Gendry will play a role in Arya’s decision to save Jon by killing Da€nerys. The mentioning of Jaehaerys’ mother might point towards Lyanna, Jon’s mother, who made Ned promise to protect Jon. This oath of protection will be fulfilled by the next generation, and Arya killing Da€nerys to save Jon is a possible scenario.

Last, not least, the septon who is killed here is named “Moon” and I just alert you to these:

“A trader from Qarth once told me that dragons came from the moon,” blond Doreah said as she warmed a towel over the fire. Jhiqui and Irri were of an age with Dany, Dothraki girls taken as slaves when Drogo destroyed their father’s khalasar. Doreah was older, almost twenty. Magister Illyrio had found her in a pleasure house in Lys.    (AGOT, Da€nerys III)

“My brother Rhaegar was a fierce warrior, my sun-and-stars,” she told him. “He died before I was born. Ser Jorah says that he was the last of the dragons.”          Khal Drogo looked down at her. His face was a copper mask, yet under the long black mustache, drooping beneath the weight of its gold rings, she thought she glimpsed the shadow of a smile. “Is good name, Dan Ares wife, moon of my life,” he said.  (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

These show clearly that Da€nerys is associated with the moon.

Now there is also a hint in one of Jon’s chapter which is usually thought to be a Jon€rys foreshadowing:

When they emerged north of the Wall, through a thick door made of freshly hewn green wood, the wildling princess paused for a moment to gaze out across the snow-covered field where King Stannis had won his battle. Beyond, the haunted forest waited, dark and silent. The light of the half-moon turned Val’s honey-blond hair a pale silver and left her cheeks as white as snow. She took a deep breath. “The air tastes sweet.”

“My tongue is too numb to tell. All I can taste is cold.” (ADWD, Jon  VIII)

With the passage from Fire and Blood in mind, this does even sound more ominous, but there is also this:

“Every man who walks the earth casts a shadow on the world. Some are thin and weak, others long and dark. You should look behind you, Lord Snow. The moon has kissed you and etched your shadow upon the ice twenty feet tall.” (ADWD, Jon VI)

This is usually also seen as a Jon€rys foreshadowing, but again with the killing of the Moon as told in F&B it is also rather ominous - neither shadows nor cold are a nice foreshadowing.

So, Arya will  - maybe for the sake of Gendry Baratheon, Lyanna and Jon himself, not necessarily on his order or wish -  kill Da€nerys, probably by slitting her throat with Catspaw. This will be the last obstacle against the acession of Jon as king and it will mean the death of the dragons as well.

Last, not least, the septon who is killed here is named “Moon” and I just alert you to these:

“A trader from Qarth once told me that dragons came from the moon,” blond Doreah said as she warmed a towel over the fire. Jhiqui and Irri were of an age with Dany, Dothraki girls taken as slaves when Drogo destroyed their father’s khalasar. Doreah was older, almost twenty. Magister Illyrio had found her in a pleasure house in Lys.    (AGOT, Da€nerys III)

“My brother Rhaegar was a fierce warrior, my sun-and-stars,” she told him. “He died before I was born. Ser Jorah says that he was the last of the dragons.”          Khal Drogo looked down at her. His face was a copper mask, yet under the long black mustache, drooping beneath the weight of its gold rings, she thought she glimpsed the shadow of a smile. “Is good name, Dan Ares wife, moon of my life,” he said.  (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

These show clearly that Da€nerys is associated with the moon.

Now there is also a hint in one of Jon’s chapter which is usually thought to be a Jon€rys foreshadowing:

When they emerged north of the Wall, through a thick door made of freshly hewn green wood, the wildling princess paused for a moment to gaze out across the snow-covered field where King Stannis had won his battle. Beyond, the haunted forest waited, dark and silent. The light of the half-moon turned Val’s honey-blond hair a pale silver and left her cheeks as white as snow. She took a deep breath. “The air tastes sweet.”

“My tongue is too numb to tell. All I can taste is cold.” (ADWD, Jon  VIII)

With the passage from Fire and Blood in mind, this does even sound more ominous, but there is also this:

“Every man who walks the earth casts a shadow on the world. Some are thin and weak, others long and dark. You should look behind you, Lord Snow. The moon has kissed you and etched your shadow upon the ice twenty feet tall.” (ADWD, Jon VI)

This is usually also seen as a Jon€rys foreshadowing, but again with the killing of the Moon as told in F&B it is also rather ominous - neither shadows nor cold are a nice foreshadowing.

So, Arya will  - maybe for the sake of Gendry Baratheon, Lyanna and Jon himself, not necessarily on his order or wish -  kill Da€nerys, probably by slitting her throat with Catspaw. This will be the last obstacle against the acession of Jon as king and it will mean the death of the dragons as well.
trail.content:
We are currently discussing this possible scenario over at @delulumeta and while looking at Fire and Blood I came across this story, which is a clear hint at Arya killing D and I just couldn’t resist the temptation to share this.

Moon’s murder removed the last major obstacle to the acession of Jaehaerys Targaryen to the Iron Throne, but from that day to this, debate has raged as to who was responsible for his death. No one truly believed that the woman who attempted to poison the “sinful septon” and ended by cutting his throat was acting on her won. Plainly she was but a catspaw … but whose? Did the boy king himself send her forth, or was she mayhaps an agent of his Hand, Rogar Baratheon, or his mother, the Queen Regent? Some came to believe that the woman was one of the Faceless Men, the infamous guild of sorcerer-assassins from Braavos. In support of this claim, they cited her sudden disappearance, the way she seemed to “melt into the night” after the murder, and the fact that Septon Moon’s guards could not agree on what she looked like.

Wiser man and those familiar with the ways of the Faceless Men give this theory little credence. The very clumsiness of Moon’s murder speaks against it being their work, for the Faceless Men take great care to make their killings appear as natural deaths. It is a point of pride with them, the very cornerstone of their art. Slitting a man’s throat and leaving him to stagger forth into the night screaming of murder is beneath them. Most scholars today believe that the killer was no more than a camp follower, acting at the behest of either Lord Rowan or Lord Oakheart, or mayhaps the both of them. Though neither dared desert Moon whilst he live, the alacrity with which the two lords abandoned his cause after his death suggests that their grievance had been with Maegor, not with House Targaryen…. and indeed, both men would soon return to Oldtown, penitent and obedient, to bend the knee before Prince Jaehaerys at his coronation. (Fire and Blood, The Ascencion of Jaehaerys I).

So, we have a female assassin who is a faceless man or maybe not - just like Arya is a female assassin who is not a real faceless man. She left the House of Black and White before her education was formerly over. Like Arya in the mercy chapter this female assassin kills her target by seducing him and then slitting his throat. In the show the ‘slitting a man’s throat’ has become something like a trademark for Arya. Also the woman meling into the night may evoke the “quiet as a shadow”-stealthiness that Arya already learned with Syrio Forel. It is also interesting that the word catspaw is used. It could be an allusion to Cat = Catelyn as Arya’s mother or to the dagger Arya wears in the show. We don’t know the dagger’s name in the books yet, but the show gives it as catspaw.

But why Da€nerys as the victim? Septon Moon is the last obstacle against the acession of Jaehaerys I, a king who clearly has parallels to Jon, Da€nerys is the last obstacle to Jon’s acession. It is also interesting that a Baratheon is involved, which might point towards the fact that Gendry will play a role in Arya’s decision to save Jon by killing Da€nerys. The mentioning of Jaehaerys’ mother might point towards Lyanna, Jon’s mother, who made Ned promise to protect Jon. This oath of protection will be fulfilled by the next generation, and Arya killing Da€nerys to save Jon is a possible scenario.

Last, not least, the septon who is killed here is named “Moon” and I just alert you to these:

“A trader from Qarth once told me that dragons came from the moon,” blond Doreah said as she warmed a towel over the fire. Jhiqui and Irri were of an age with Dany, Dothraki girls taken as slaves when Drogo destroyed their father’s khalasar. Doreah was older, almost twenty. Magister Illyrio had found her in a pleasure house in Lys.    (AGOT, Da€nerys III)

“My brother Rhaegar was a fierce warrior, my sun-and-stars,” she told him. “He died before I was born. Ser Jorah says that he was the last of the dragons.”          Khal Drogo looked down at her. His face was a copper mask, yet under the long black mustache, drooping beneath the weight of its gold rings, she thought she glimpsed the shadow of a smile. “Is good name, Dan Ares wife, moon of my life,” he said.  (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

These show clearly that Da€nerys is associated with the moon.

Now there is also a hint in one of Jon’s chapter which is usually thought to be a Jon€rys foreshadowing:

When they emerged north of the Wall, through a thick door made of freshly hewn green wood, the wildling princess paused for a moment to gaze out across the snow-covered field where King Stannis had won his battle. Beyond, the haunted forest waited, dark and silent. The light of the half-moon turned Val’s honey-blond hair a pale silver and left her cheeks as white as snow. She took a deep breath. “The air tastes sweet.”

“My tongue is too numb to tell. All I can taste is cold.” (ADWD, Jon  VIII)

With the passage from Fire and Blood in mind, this does even sound more ominous, but there is also this:

“Every man who walks the earth casts a shadow on the world. Some are thin and weak, others long and dark. You should look behind you, Lord Snow. The moon has kissed you and etched your shadow upon the ice twenty feet tall.” (ADWD, Jon VI)

This is usually also seen as a Jon€rys foreshadowing, but again with the killing of the Moon as told in F&B it is also rather ominous - neither shadows nor cold are a nice foreshadowing.

So, Arya will  - maybe for the sake of Gendry Baratheon, Lyanna and Jon himself, not necessarily on his order or wish -  kill Da€nerys, probably by slitting her throat with Catspaw. This will be the last obstacle against the acession of Jon as king and it will mean the death of the dragons as well.

summary: Here's one thing people seem to forget while talking about Jon and Dany risking their lives to protect the North. Sansa did that...
body:
Here’s one thing people seem to forget while talking about Jon and Dany risking their lives to protect the North. Sansa did that too.

Escaping from Ramsay was a risk. Then she wanted Jon to help her with defeating Ramsay and returning Winterfell (and the North) to Starks, but, as she said, if he didn’t join her, she’d try herself. And she told Jon, that if they fail, she’ll never return to Ramsay. She gave herself a choice: beeing alive and safe in Winterfell as Sansa Stark or death. Two options, one of them includes her death.

When you choose to fight, even knowing that if you fail - you die, that means you’re risking your life. I won’t ever believe most of got fandom is that dumb to condiser that “risking your life is when you take a sword and fight your enemies with it!!!!11”
